revisions.rev:
{{Infobox racing driver | name = Michael Mario Andretti | image = Michael Andretti 2007 Michigan.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Andretti at Michigan in 2007 | nationality = [[United States|American]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1962|10|5}} | birth_place = [[Bethlehem, Pennsylvania|Bethlehem]], [[Pennsylvania]] | related to = [[Mario Andretti]] (father)

[[Newman/Haas/Lanigan Racing|Newman/Haas Racing]] | starts = 317 | wins = 42 | poles = 32 | fastest laps = | best finish = 1st | year = [[1991 IndyCar season|1991]] | prev series = [[Champ Car|CART IndyCar World Series]]

1994-2002 | titles = 1 | title years = 1991 | awards = CART IndyCar World Series Champion | award years = 1991 }} {{Infobox F1 driver| name = | nationality = {{flagicon|USA}} American| birth_date = | Years = {{F1|1993}} | Team(s) = [[McLaren (racing)|McLaren]] | Races = 13 | Championships = 0 | Wins = 0 | Podiums = 1 | Points = 7 | Poles = 0 | Fastest laps = 0 | First race = [[1993 South African Grand Prix]] | First win = | Last win = | Last race = [[1993 Italian Grand Prix]] | }} [[File:MichaelAndretti.jpg|right|thumb|Andretti racing at [[Monterey, California]], October 1991]] [[File:MarcoAndMichaelAndrettiPracticing2007Indy500.jpg|thumb|right|Michael (right) practicing against [[Marco Andretti|Marco]] at Indy]] [[File:1989Porsche962MarioAndrettiMichaelAndrettiMillerHighLife.jpg|thumb|right|Michael and Mario's 1989 [[Porsche 962]] driven in the [[24 Hours of Daytona]].]] [[File:Michael Andretti 2008 Indy 500 Bump Day.jpg|right|thumb|Andretti at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in May 2008.]] '''Michael Mario Andretti''' (born October 5, 1962) is a retired [[United States|American]] [[Champ Car|CART]] and [[Formula One]] driver and owner of the [[Andretti Autosport]] team in the [[IndyCar Series]]. Andretti is the son of [[Mario Andretti]]. His son is [[Marco Andretti]]. ==Racing career== ===Early career=== Andretti started racing in 1980, driving a [[Formula Vee]] car in Local SCCA events. In 1981 he won six of the 11 Super Vee races and won the championship.[http://www.texacohavoline42.com/media/history/cart/michael_andretti.asp Texaco/Havoline CART History Michael Andretti] He moved on to drive in [[Formula Atlantic]], and won the Championship in 1983. In the same year he joined his father and Philippe Alliot in the Porsche Kremer Racing Team, taking third place in the [[1983 24 Hours of Le Mans|Le Mans 24 Hours]], driving a Porsche 956. ===CART=== He made his [[Champ Car|CART]] debut in [[1984 IndyCar season|1984]], racing for the Kraco team. He managed five third place finishes and ended the season in seventh overall. In the [[1984 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]], he finished fifth and shared the [[List of Indianapolis 500 Rookies of the Year|Rookie of the Year]] award with Roberto Guerrero. He went on to win his first [[American Championship Car Racing|IndyCar]] race in [[1986 IndyCar season|1986]] at [[Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach|Long Beach]], finishing that year as championship runner-up after collecting other wins at [[Milwaukee Mile|Milwaukee]] and [[Phoenix International Raceway|Phoenix]]. Andretti achieved major title success by winning the [[1991 IndyCar season|1991]] [[Champ Car|CART]]/[[PPG Industries|PPG]] IndyCar World Series for [[Newman/Haas/Lanigan Racing|Newman/Haas Racing]]. He won 8 of 17 races; [[ABC Supply Company A.J. Foyt 225|Milwaukee]], [[Steelback Grand Prix of Toronto|Toronto]], [[Molson Indy Vancouver|Vancouver]], the [[Marlboro Challenge]], and all 5 permanent road course events ([[Grand Prix of Portland|Portland]], [[Grand Prix of Cleveland|Cleveland]], [[Honda 200|Mid-Ohio]], [[Champ Car Grand Prix of Road America|Road America]], and [[Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca#CART/Champ Car|Laguna Seca]]). ===Futility at Indianapolis=== The Andretti family's bad luck at the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] is known as the [[Andretti Curse]]. As a driver, he is largely remembered for being unlucky at the [[Indianapolis 500]]. In [[1991 Indianapolis 500|1991]], he led with twelve laps remaining, but finished second to [[Rick Mears]] after battling the multiple Indy 500 winner. In [[1992 Indianapolis 500|1992]], he dominated the race, leading a full four-fifths of the laps, but, with eleven laps remaining, his fuel pump failed, and his car coasted to a stop. He finished in 13th place. He also dropped out while leading the Indy 500 in [[1989 Indianapolis 500|1989]], [[1995 Indianapolis 500|1995]] and [[2003 Indianapolis 500|2003]]. Michael holds the record for [[List of Indianapolis 500 lap leaders|most laps led]] in the Indy 500 without having achieved a victory. ===Formula One=== After his 1991 CART title win, Andretti joined the [[McLaren (racing)|McLaren]] [[Formula One]] team for [[1993 Formula One season|1993]], alongside the triple World Champion [[Ayrton Senna]]. He signed on in September 1992.{{cite news| url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE7DB1F3FF93BA3575AC0A964958260&scp=74&sq=gerhard%20berger&st=cse | work=The New York Times | title=SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING; Andretti Switches to McLaren Team | date=September 8, 1992}} Unfortunately, the season was not a success. A string of collisions meant that he only completed three laps in his first three races, and he never fully got to grips with [[Formula One car]]s. Highly technical aspects which he was not used to in the [[American Championship Car Racing#Machines|technologically simpler IndyCars]] such as [[active suspension]] and [[traction control system|traction control]] hampered Andretti's chances for the 1993 F1 season. This combined with the fact that he commuted to races and test sessions from the [[United States of America|USA]], rather than re-locating full-time to [[Europe]] were also contributing factors to his lack of success in Formula One. Three points-scoring finishes, including a third place at [[Autodromo Nazionale Monza|Monza]], were perceived as too little, too late, and he left the team and the series by mutual agreement after that race. However, according to son [[Marco Andretti|Marco]], the McLaren team Andretti drove for "sabotaged" his chances at being competitive in order to replace him with [[Finland|Finnish]] driver [[Mika HÃ¤kkinen]], who would require a smaller salary. "The reality of it was, they had Mika HÃ¤kkinen ready to come in for a lot less than what my dad was getting paid, and that's all it was. Right then and there, they had to make him look [bad]," claimed Marco in 2008. "They would make the car do weird things in the corner electronically, stuff out of his control.'"[http://www.nwherald.com/articles/2008/05/22/sports/other_sports/doc4835195490406345041530.txt Andretti: F1 team tried to âsabotageâ dadâs career] ''Northwest Herald'' Retrieved 29 June 2008 However, Andretti still had problems in practice at [[1993 Italian Grand Prix|Monza]], and both he and Senna spun off with brake balance problems early in the race. Andretti was able to continue and fought back up to third, holding off [[Karl Wendlinger]]. Throughout the season, Senna experienced similar reliability problems to Andretti, mainly electronic gremlins, particularly in [[1993 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino]], [[1993 Canadian Grand Prix|Canada]], [[1993 Hungarian Grand Prix|Hungary]] and [[1993 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgium]].[http://atlasf1.autosport.com/2000/ita/okeefe.html] "Atlas F1 - Man for One Season" Retrieved 29 June 2008 After Andretti's departure, both Senna and HÃ¤kkinen continued to have reliability issues,[http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/rr546.html] 1993 Portuguese GP report[http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/rr548.html] 1993 Australian GP report although HÃ¤kkinen equalled Andretti's third place Monza finish in [[1993 Japanese Grand Prix|Japan]]. At the start of the 1993 season, [[Ron Dennis]] signed HÃ¤kkinen as a backup to Senna, who was initially reluctant to commit to the team for the whole season. The ''F1 Rejects'' website states that this created a difficult atmosphere for Andretti, who would be in the shadow of the three-time F1 champion Senna, and also faced the threat of being replaced by HÃ¤kkinen.[http://www.f1rejects.com/centrale/andretti/index.html Michael Andretti] ''F1 Rejects'' Retrieved 29 June 2008 After Andretti's unsuccessful Formula 1 season, he never returned to the cockpit in that series. ===Return to CART=== After [[McLaren (racing)|McLaren]] replaced Andretti with HÃ¤kkinen, Michael returned to the [[Champ Car|CART series]] for [[1994 IndyCar season|1994]] and drove for [[Chip Ganassi Racing|Chip Ganassi]], where he once again proved very successful. He went on to win in his very first race back in the series at the [[1994 Australian FAI Indycar Grand Prix|Surfers Paradise event]] in [[Australia]], having led every lap along the way. That win also got [[Reynard Motorsport|Reynard]]'s first win in CART in their debut. In [[1995 IndyCar season|1995]] he returned to [[Newman/Haas Racing]]. He finished as runner-up to [[Jimmy Vasser]] in [[1996 IndyCar season|1996]] and more race wins followed in the years to come, but his [[1991 IndyCar season|1991 championship success]] remained his only title in [[American Championship Car Racing|CART/IndyCar racing]]. His career in CART ended in [[2002 CART season|2002]], in which he took his 42nd and final career victory at the [[Long Beach Grand Prix]] - placing him in third place for all-time victories in championship car racing behind his father, [[Mario Andretti]] (52 wins) and [[A.J. Foyt]] (67 wins). Michael Andretti is also tied with [[Al Unser, Jr.]] for the most wins in a CART/IndyCar season with eight victories. He achieved this during [[1991 IndyCar season|his championship-winning season of 1991]]. ==Sports cars== Michael has driven in numerous sports car races at different times in his career. Many were Andretti family efforts, especially with his father Mario. ==Semi-retirement and team owner== After competing in the [[2003 Indianapolis 500]], Andretti retired from full-time IndyCar racing. He led the race for 28 of the opening 94 laps before a throttle linkage failure put him out of contention once again. That year he bought into the "Team Green" squad run by brothers Kim and Barry Green in [[Champ Car|CART]]. It became [[Andretti Green Racing]] and for [[2003 IndyCar Series season|2003]] the team moved to the [[Indy Racing League]] [[IndyCar Series]]. That year, [[Tony Kanaan]] won the [[2004 IndyCar Series season|2004 IndyCar Series]] Championship for Andretti Green Racing. In [[2005 IndyCar Series season|2005]], Britain's [[Dan Wheldon]] won the [[2005 Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]], and the Championship for the team. In [[2007 IndyCar Series season|2007]], Scotland's [[Dario Franchitti]] won the Indianapolis 500 and the IndyCar Series title for AGR. ===Return to racing at Indy=== Andretti returned to the driver's seat for the [[2006 Indianapolis 500]] in a one-time effort to assist the development of his son, [[Marco Andretti|Marco]], an IndyCar rookie for the [[2006 IndyCar Series season|'06 season]]. Michael led the race with four laps to go, before falling to second behind his son a lap later. He went on to finish third, while Marco only just missed out on the 500 victory after he was passed just before the start/finish line on the last lap by three-time Indycar champion [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] After qualifying his car in 11th place for the [[2007 Indianapolis 500]], Andretti went on to finish 13th. He then announced that this would be his last Indy 500 as a driver. Andretti leaves driving competition at Indy with a frustrating distinction - the driver who's led the most laps (431) without winning the race. He competed in 16 Indy 500s, with a top finish of second in [[1991 Indianapolis 500|1991]], but led the race nine times. As a car owner, however, he has far more success. In [[2005 Indianapolis 500|2005]], only three years after Andretti acquired primary ownership of the team, Andretti-Green Racing (AGR) saw its first 500 triumph come from [[Dan Wheldon]] in the #26 Klein Tools Special entry, and in 2007 an even stronger second victory, from [[Scotland|Scottish]] driver [[Dario Franchitti]] in the #27 Canadian Club-sponsored car, who won the rain-shortened event at the completion of 166 of the scheduled 200 laps, but after another AGR team driver, [[Tony Kanaan]], had himself led half of the eventual laps, and showed potential of renewing his challenge for supremacy after a fourth turn late-race incident. ==Personal life== Andretti was married to Sandra Spinozzi from November 1985 to 1996 and they had two children, son [[Marco Andretti|Marco]] (born March 13, 1987) and daughter Marissa (born October 31, 1990). He remarried on December 24, 1997 to Leslie Wood. They had a son, Lucca, born September 16, 1999. On September 7, 2004 Andretti filed for divorce. Two years later on July 15, 2006 Andretti announced his engagement to former [[Miss Oregon Teen USA]] 1994, model, actress and 2000 ''[[Playboy]]'' [[Playboy Playmate|Playmate]] of the Year [[Jodi Ann Paterson]]. The couple were married on October 7, 2006 at the Andretti Winery in Napa Valley, California. ==Andretti family== Michael is from the famous Andretti racing family. He is the son of [[Formula 1]], CART and [[NASCAR]] racing legend [[Mario Andretti]]. His brother [[Jeff Andretti]] competed in IndyCar. Michael's uncle [[Aldo Andretti]] was an open wheel racer until an accident ended his racing career. Aldo's son [[John Andretti]] (Michael's first cousin) raced in IndyCar before he became a NASCAR regular. He returned to IndyCar in 2007, 2008, 2009 and 2010 to race the Indy 500, and will race in the 2011 edition too. Aldo's other son, [[Adam Andretti|Adam]] also is a racecar driver, and in 2005, Michael's son Marco began his career in Indy Racing. The Andretti family became the first family to have five relatives (Michael, Mario, Marco, Jeff, and John) compete in the same series (CART/[[Champ Car]]/Indycar).{{cite web | author=Schwartz, Larry | title=Mario Andretti synonymous with racing | publisher=[[ESPN]] | work=[[Motorsports Hall of Fame of America]] | url=http://espn.go.com/sportscentury/features/00014066.html | accessdate=2007-02-22 }} Michael Andretti has an estate upon an adjacent tract of land to his father's mansion of "Montona" in Nazareth, Pennsylvania, where he grew up. However that property was listed for sale in January 2008 for $3.4 million.[http://www.nj.com/news/expresstimes/pa/index.ssf?/base/news-15/120037351299150.xml&coll=2 Story not found - NJ.com] His sister Barbara is the listing agent and said Michael has several other homes and will always have a Nazareth connection. Michael's other homes include a property in downtown Indianapolis where his son lives (near his championship race team headquarters), a residence in Miami Beach, and several other properties for investment purposes. He was elected into the Motorsports Hall of Fame in 2008 and the Long Beach Grand Prix Walk of Fame in 2010. ==Motorsports career results== ===Complete 24 Hours of Le Mans results=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90% |- !
